text.__SUMMARY__: The Arizona myotis (Myotis occultus) is a vesper bat species inhabiting much of the southwestern United States and central Mexico as far south as the Distrito Federal.
text.Taxonomy and etymology:
It was described as a new species in 1909 by American zoologist Ned Hollister.
The holotype was collected near Needles, California in 1905.
Its species name "occultus" is Latin for "hidden or concealed."
text.Description:
It is a small species with a total length of 96 mm (3.8 in)— of the total length, 40 mm (1.6 in) consists of its tail.
Its fur is glossy brown with a cinnamon tint.
The ventral fur and its face are paler brown.
text.Range and habitat:
Its range includes parts of the Southwestern United States and the Mexican state of Chihuahua.
It is found in a range of elevations from near sea level to 2,806 m (9,206 ft) above sea level.
text.Conservation:
As of 2018, it is evaluated as a least-concern species by the IUCN.
It meets the criteria for this classification because it has a wide geographic range, its range includes protected areas, and it is not likely experiencing rapid population decline.
